text:
Fun fact, in addition to being
the former Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for
South and Southeast Asia,

Joe was also the first
user of Palantir, right? Is that how you-- No, that's legitimately
a true story.

Yeah, this is a-- I don't know how you haven't
put this on your resume yet. Joe was the first outside of
Palantir user of Palantir.

Great. Great. Well, Trae, Joe gave a little
bit on your background, but we'd love to add a little
bit more color to that.

You grew up in rural
America as we now know. You were a senior in high
school when 9/11 happened.

And you knocked down doors
to get into Georgetown. Would love to just
hear more about

why you decided to go to
Georgetown, end up in DC, just some of the early years
in the intelligence community

as well? Sure. I think one of the
things that I took for granted as a
hard-charging student

in a rural public school is
that it's actually really hard to get into college.

I think I had assumed that as
long as I had really good test scores and really good grades
and good extracurriculars,

it's just going to
be a clean path. And I basically got rejected
everywhere that I applied.

Incidentally, I did
get into one school. It was UNC Chapel Hill. And my high school
girlfriend had already

planned to go to Elon,
which is not too far away from UNC Chapel Hill. And I went over to
her house that night. And I was devastated I got
all these skinny envelopes.

And I'm like, well,
at least we're going to go to college
close to each other. And she was like, yeah, about
that-- and broke up with me--

[LAUGHTER] --the same day that I got
all these skinny envelopes. And in retrospect,
I can look back,

and it's clear that was
maybe the best thing that ever happened to me
because I'm like, I'm not going to
UNC Chapel Hill.

I'm going to go to the
place that I want to go and that's Georgetown. And so yeah, I mean, Joe
told the story accurately.

I showed up, and I demanded
to see the dean of admissions. And I dumped a bunch of
recommendation letters

on his table. And I think he
thought I was crazy. But then, ultimately,
they let me in.

And it's amazing the way that
the American academic culture

works is that probably the most
important decision for setting the framework for your
career is a decision that we

ask 18-year-olds to make. And there's like a
tremendous amount of pressure like what would have happened
if I had gone the easy path

and just said like, OK, I'm
going to go to Ohio State because this is a sure thing. I don't think I would be
doing any of the things

that I'm doing today. Not even that Ohio
State is a bad school. It's just like you're
all here at Stanford. This is great. It's going to be a great
launch pad for you in life.

But had to make that decision
when you were 18 years old. That's crazy that we
expect that of teenagers.

So anyway-- Paul and I were just
awing on your story. It's really much very
much how government sales

works as well, which is you
got a bunch of no's and knocked

down some doors and-- Government relations
from the day one. --got that yes. Yeah, I'm not sure
that's a good lesson.

But yeah, no, it's true. It requires a lot of extra
steps that you probably shouldn't have to go through.

Yeah, but we'll talk about
your reinvention down the line. So out of Georgetown you go
into intelligence community.

And then talk about how you
got hooked up with Palantir and that interesting repivot.

You've been working
IC for years. Yeah, I saw a demo actually. And In-Q-Tel had already made
an investment in Palantir,

and they were road showing
it around the community. And I saw a demo
and thought, wow,

this would revolutionize
my day to day. And tried to make this
argument that this

is the thing that we should do. And it turns out that
there was very little institutional interest
in licensing software

from a Silicon Valley company. And so just ran into
a bunch of roadblocks. Started talking with the
team at Palantir, which

was only like 15 or 20 people. They had no revenue. I didn't know that at the
time, but they had no revenue.

And I ended up going and
talking to them and said, I hope you're not wasting
your time because this

is going nowhere internally. Like I've seen it
from the inside. It's not going anywhere.

And the guy at Palantir that
I was talking to just laughed and he said, you
probably think you're

going to spend the rest of
your career as a civil servant. But I'm going to
tell you right now, the attitude that
you're showing,

you're not going to make it. You should really
come out and join us. And so I spent one day in
Palo Alto with the team

and went home and started
talking to my to my wife. And she was like, I don't want
to see you unhappy anymore.

This seems like a much better
path and off to the races. Talk about that because I
think the contrast between you

and your wife's thinking around
strategy and decision making, talk about that. It's pretty interesting. Yeah, I mean, I'm like--
this is going to sound weird

from a multi-time entrepreneur
and a venture capitalist, but I'm risk averse.

Not in a actual risk
aversion kind of way. More in a I'm highly
analytical, and I

don't do impulsive
decision making very well. My wife is the opposite.

she's like ready to go
on a moment's notice. And so I'll come home with like
this package of information.

Like, here's how I'm
thinking about this. These are the pros and the cons. And she's like, the
answer is obviously this. You should just go do it.

And that's been important
at every stage of my career. Like in every step, it was her
kind of prodding me saying,

stop dragging your feet. You have to run through this
door with a full head of steam. And that was true with not
only Palantir that transition

from government
over to Palantir. It was also true of
Palantir to Founders Fund. I had no interest
in venture capital.

I didn't even know
venture capital was. My only exposure to it was
in the movie Wedding Crashers where they told people they
were venture capitalists.

That was my exposure
to the world. And then also with
starting Anduril just

having someone behind me
just pushing me out the door has been tremendously valuable.

What were the early
days of Palantir like? Oh, man, it was a much slower
start than people remember.

The company was started in 2004. And when I joined
in 2008, again, there was there was no revenue.

It was super, super early. So it took a long time to build. They had gone through like
multiple iterations of product

development to try to get it
to a minimally viable place to start shipping
to the customers.

And it was a long hard slog. Both Palantir and Space X had
roughly the same trajectory

to their first $10
million in revenue. It was over five years, which is
pretty crazy if you think about from a startup perspective.

That's dead zone. You can't go that long. What did you do
differently on Palantir?

Man, I don't know--
they didn't really have any shoulders to stand on. And so it wasn't like they could
have run an Anduril strategy

because the Anduril strategy
in many ways relied on Palantir and Space X working before us.

I think probably
the biggest mistake that we made that was
tactical was we didn't

hire lobbyists for a long time. And I think one of the core
lessons from that experience is that you can't play the
outsider game entirely.

You have to have
an inside baseball game that you run alongside
of the outsider strategy. So that's probably
the biggest thing.

So we get really personal here. We talk about the first day of
Palantir and you start coding. Yeah. Can we can we hit
that highlight?

Yeah, so I was not a
good software engineer. I was maybe passable inside
of the federal government.

But then showing up on
my first day at Palantir, I was tinkering around and
they had these exercises

that they would run
new hires through. And I was dinking around and one
of the software engineers who

I'd never met before walks up
to the desk and he's like, hi. I'm such and such. I won't sell him out.

We are recording this. He was like, hi,
I'm such and such. Who are you? And I was like, oh, I'm Trae. Today is my first day. And he was like, you're a
terrible software engineer.

I'm blocking you
from the code base. And so like most
software companies work,

they were like, OK, Trae
is a bad software engineer, but he's more extroverted
than the rest of us, so he's now in charge of.

Sales [LAUGHTER] And so that was my
path as I ended up running what we called
the Leverage Team.

I don't know if any of
you have looked too deeply into Palantir, but
historically, the company has said that they
don't have a sales team.

And that was largely true
except that we had a team called Leverage that was
basically the sales team, and that's what I was in
charge of for the six years

that I was there. And then you joined
Founders Fund. What prompted you to? It was January, 2014.

So we're coming up on I got a call from Peter Thiel,
who is the co-founder, chairman

of Palantir. And he and I worked
together a lot because I was doing the
strategic sales stuff,

and he was always-- The not-engineering stuff. --the not-engineering stuff. And so he called me out
of the blue and said,

hey, are you familiar
with Founders Fund. And I'm like, I'm familiar
with the venture fund that you started.

And he was like, yeah, so we're
about to raise this billion dollar institutional fund.

It's the largest fund
that we've ever run. And I really want to
build out our talent base. And I would love for
you to come join it.

And I was like,
in what capacity? Because you're my
boss at Palantir.

So I'm still your employee. And he was like, no, no, no,
I want you to leave Palantir,

move to San Francisco. I was in DC at the time. He's like, move to San Francisco
and work at a venture fund

full-time. And I'm like, isn't
that a finance job? And he's like,
that's a finance job. I'm like, I don't know
anything about finance.

What are we talking about here? So it was completely
out of the blue. And he just kept up
over nine months.

The call was in march
of 2013, and he just kept poking me all
the way through 2013.

And then right at the end
of the year, he was like, you got to do this. It's the right decision. It's going to make
everyone happy.

So I left. And then you talked
to your wife. No, I talked to my wife. And my wife was like,
yeah, this is obviously what you should do.

So it was one of those
weird moments where I'm stepping into the unknown.

It's like your
reinventing yourself as a venture capitalist. So talk about the first couple
of years what did you do?

Well, I mean, because I didn't
know anything about venture, I didn't feel like I
was in a good position

to just outbound to
enterprise SaaS companies.

I didn't feel like I really
had anything to offer there. So I did two things. The first thing is that I
told everyone on the team

that I wanted to join
their pitch meetings. Because it turns
out that the best way to learn how to be good at
venture capital is by osmosis.

You just have to take
an enormous amount of pitch meetings. And the quality
almost doesn't matter. It's like you want to
just like any inbound.

People would just
forward it to me, and I would take the meeting. It didn't matter
how stupid it was. And I did that for
an entire year.

And I crossed 500 meetings in my
first year, which there's 365-- And these weren't Zoom.

These are in-person. These are in-person meetings. Real meetings. Yeah. And so it might not
sound like a huge number, but 500 is an enormous
amount of pitch meetings

for one year in VC. And so I hit I think 502. And I told the team at the end
of the year I'm like, I did it.

And they're like,
what were you doing? That is a terrible idea.

Yeah, you're right. It was a pretty dumb idea. But it ended up making two
big investments that year.

One in Flexport, which is
now a $9 billion valuation

supply chain logistics company. And the other in a
company called Expanse. It used to be called Qadium,
which was acquired by Palo Alto

networks for $1 billion. You're two for two
in your first year? Two for two my first year,
which I don't honestly have

any idea how that happened. But then I also was
running this strategy on national security,
which is I guess

what brings us here today. So recognizing that
the one area that I had some edge in--
and by edge I mean

I have some secret or some
advantage against the rest of the venture capital
market was defense tech

because that's where I'd
spent my entire career. And so I luckily had access
to two different databases.

One is FedBizOpps. So you know all of the
people all the companies that are bidding on
federal contracts.

And then also PitchBook
Or PitchBook equivalents, which is basically a database
of all venture-backed technology

companies. And I just started running
cross postings on them. Like, pull down all the
people bidding on contracts.

Check to see if they've
raised venture capital. Outbound to the founders
to try to get a meeting. And the idea was maybe there's
another Palantir and Space

X out there. And Founders Fund is one of the
largest institutional investors in both of those companies. So like maybe we have an edge.

We can find the
next one, and it's going to be massive
and successful. Other than Expanse I
didn't find anything.

I just came up short. And even in retrospect
almost 10 years later,

it's not like we
missed anything. There wasn't a company that came
out had that sort of scaling.

And going through meeting these
literally over 100 companies, I came to the realization
that a lot of the things that

were really hard
at Palantir were related to selling
software being really hard.

And we can talk about
why I think that is. It was the team
construction mattered a lot.

A lot of really bad strategies
that companies had employed that was advice that they
were getting from consultants

and other things that
just didn't map at all to the success model
that Palantir and Space X have worked out.
And so I went back to the team. And this was 2015. It was July I think of 2015.

And I said, guys, this
company doesn't exist, but what we really
need is we need a Stark

Industries from Iron Man. We need a 21st
century defense prime that builds across the product
suite, is focused on platforms,

winning big core things
that are going to be funded for decades at a time. And the core capability
has to be software

because all the things
we actually need are software capabilities. But you can't sell
software, so somebody

needs to Trojan horse
wrap the software in different shapes
of metal and then sell

that metal to the DOD. And to my surprise, Peter
and the rest of the team they were like,
OK, well, it sounds

like you know what to do. Go start a company. I'm like, Peter, I'm
so fricking confused. You're like, you don't
want me doing Palantir.

You want me doing finance. Now you don't want
me doing finance. You want me to do Anduril. He was like, no,
you can do both.

Everybody's happy. So what were the early
days like in terms of how did you recruit the team?

How did Anduril come together? Yeah, I mean-- Lean startup. Totally. Yeah, I mean, this
is a lot of lessons

from people like Steve and Joe. If you haven't watched
Steve's Secret History

of Silicon Valley, I would
recommend that you do it. I actually watched
that video on that same first day at
Palantir where I got

told that I wasn't allowed
to write code anymore. I watched his video the Secret
History of Silicon Valley.

And these concepts
around lean startup really were played out in the
way that we built Anduril.

It was like a lot of
guessing and testing. The first thing
that I had to do,

obviously, was recruit
a cofounding team. And so I went out to
my closest friends

that I had worked with
before, which this is a great hack by the way. One of the core problems that
you'll see in most startups

is cofounder drama, like
conflict between the founding

members of the team. If you start the
company with people that you have a decade
plus relationship with,

the probability of that
happening is much lower. And so I went out to Palmer. We were the first institutional
investor in Oculus.

I knew he was really interested
in national security. I started pitching him on this
idea of a 21st century defense

prime. And he was like, oh,
you have to come out to my house in Woodside. I'm building a ramjet
in my swimming pool.

And sure enough, he had
drained his swimming pool, and he was building a
ramjet in his swimming pool. As everyone in--

As everyone in-- yeah. He was like, yeah, I've had
a couple of noise violations. Cops have come out. I'm like, yeah, because you
have a ramjet in your swimming

pool in Woodside. That's going to happen. And then the guy who
was running engineering at Palantir, Brian Schimpf.

He was the hardest
sell actually. He was not convinced-- How long did it take? It took-- I started talking
to him probably in late 2016,

call it October,
November of 2016. And he didn't sign on
until I think May of 2017. The first day of the
company was June 5, 2017.

So it was like a six-month sale. And then Matt Grimm, who
ran commercial for Palantir.

Brilliant guy but
maybe more importantly, he's like the incredible
fricking hulk. He's just a rage monster and
probably the best operator

I've ever worked
with in my life. Like, you send him something. You're like, hey, can
you take a look at this? And then like it's
done 5 minutes later.

And you're like, I don't
even know how you did that. I'm not going to ask questions. I'm just glad that it's done. And then Joe Chen who was very
early with Palmer at Oculus

and was also a reserve
officer in the Army.

And what did you do
differently in building Anduril versus Palantir's early days?

We literally hired a lobbyist in
the first week of the company. So we started the
company on a Monday,

the anniversary of D-day. And then on that Wednesday,
me, Palmer, and Brian had a meeting with
government officials

who ended up being
our first customers. Literally, like three
days into the company, we met with our
first customers who

now have a multi
hundred million dollar program of record with us. And then on the fifth
day, that Friday, we

were meeting with
members of congress. This is one week. So we basically just
accelerated the strategy

by not doing all
of the stupid stuff that I did in the six
years at Palantir.

Sometimes people,
other defense founders, will come to me asking
for advice on things. And they'll be like,
oh, we've been talking

to all these consultants. We've been talking to all
these retired generals. And they have all these ideas of
things that we should be doing,

and your advice is
totally different. How did you come to that? And I'm like, because
I did literally all

of the things the
consultants told you to do, and none of them work. I made all of these mistakes.

And so we just
shortcutted all that by not doing all the things
that I knew didn't work.

And I just want to context this. So this is 2017, right? So this is when national
security is not a hot topic.

There were not a lot of VCs. When you came into we
invest in the seed round, you had to teach us about just
war theory and deterrence.

So I do think let's just talk
about the ethics of defense. This is a topic you blog about.

I think now it's a
lot more understood but back then it was not. Just kind of walk through that
arc and the importance of it?

Yeah, I mean there is 2000 years
of scholarship on this topic.

It's not a new thing. I think in moments of
high political volatility, people tend to forget about
it, and they're mostly

just responding emotionally to
circumstances in the moment. But just war theory is
not about any interest

in conducting violence. That's not what any of this is
about I'm a huge Star Wars fan,

so I'm going to be a
super Star Wars nerd. But Yoda makes this
very clear when he says,

"war does not make one great." And I think that is
the unifying theory of all Western democracies
when it comes to defense.

In fact, in our not so distant
past, the Department of Defense used to be called the
Department of War.

But we changed that because
that's not what any of us want. We're not optimizing for war.

And it doesn't matter which
political party is in control of the White House, it is by far
the most bipartisan department

in the federal government. The National Defense
Authorization Act is one of the only
bills that passes every single year with a
supermajority through Congress.

Everyone understands that
defense and deterrence is really important to not
only the national security

and our ability to do the
things that we do every day, but it's also important
to economic resiliency. It's important to supply chain.

It's important to the promotion
of human rights, civil rights globally. And so we get hung
up on this idea

that oh, you're
building a missile. You're building something that
has lethality attached to it.

But really-- and I don't
want to put any of that aside because that's
very real, and it is like potentially very
scary to think about what

some of these things can do. At the same time, the goal
is not to use those weapons.

The goal is to
leverage the advantage that those technologies
give you to deter conflict

from happening in
the first place. And just war theory
talks about this in a variety of different ways. It talks about it
with just cause.

Do you have the
information that you need to make effective
decisions to prevent the unnecessary loss of life?

This is when it comes to
intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance. Are you powering the engine
that fuels just cause?

It comes through
proportionality. When someone attacks you,
are you attacking them with a massive
response in retaliation

that outweighs the attack
that they made against you? It comes to the principle
of discrimination.

Like, how careful and precise
are you being with your attack?

One way to think about
this in modern warfare is that we started at the
beginning of human civilization

punching each other. And then it was then we used
rocks, and then we used swords. Like, it got more
and more violent.

And we went from
swords to explosives and then the atomic bomb.

And then, humanity across
the board realized wow, this is really crazy. We could literally eradicate,
extinct human civilization.

And since then, we've
been crawling our way back down the curve. Weapons have become
much more precise.

Casualties have ramped
way down in every conflict that we've had. And the goal of the
principle of discrimination

is, how accurate can we become? Can we become so accurate
that we can only take out the exact targets that
we're interested in taking

out, and in doing so create
a deterrent impact so that larger conflict
doesn't break out and casualties won't be caused.

And one really clear
example of this is the Zawahiri takedown
which happened in 2021, I

want to say, September of 2021. If any of you
follow this closely,

he was taken out with
what's called a Ginsu AIM-9. Literally, nonexplosive.

It's just a missile that spins,
and it took out only him.

It hit the roof. Took out him. No collateral. The building is still standing. It didn't even blow
up the building.

And these sorts of
highly precise attacks are the future of a more
just execution of strategy,

not a less just
execution of strategy. And that's really what we're
focused on at Anduril is autonomy, precision, taking
the men and women who are

protecting our
country out of harm's. Way And how do you
think about religion

as well I know that's a big part
of what defines you as well?

The three Silicon Valley
no-nos, defense, government, and religion. It's kind of--

Yeah. And Peter takes the contrarian
thing very seriously and has boxed me
in pretty tight.

Yeah, I mean, I have always
loved philosophy and theology.

And I think I've come to
this place in my career where the connection of the
things that I personally

hold very dear particularly
on the theological side find their way
bleeding into the stuff

that I'm most interested in. And I think that just war
theory for what it's worth

was originated by
Saint Augustine. It's a Christian
tradition that's now part of the entire
Western canon for the way

that we think about violence. And I think that taking
that and thinking

through moral code
and natural right and where we
establish the ethics for how we engage
with one another,

not only in a defense
context but also civically is a really important
exercise just to make sure

that we have a
foundational truth that we're checking
back to and not just

like cascading into nihilism. Because if you're
cascading into nihilism, you have no foundational
truth, no natural right

that you're holding up. Then you're really
only operating on the highest
ideals of a society.

And I think it would
be very easy to look at like the Russian
perspective on Ukraine and say they're operating
inside the highest

ideals of their society. Do we believe that they
have a natural right to execute the highest
ideals of their society,

or do we believe that
there are governors that need to be put on
that to ensure justice

of that, but we are at least
responsible for speaking truth into those things. Opportunities ahead-- what are
you thinking for this sector?

Yeah, I mean, it
it's really hard. I think there's a big difference
between the defense technology

space and enterprise
SaaS 10 years ago.

A lot of the most talented
people in the technology ecosystem behave
in a similar way

to George Clooney
and the Kardashians. I'll explain why. George Clooney says
I have a huge name.

I have a great brand. My organic advantage
in distribution is very, very high, so I'm
going to start a tequila brand

or whatever he sells. I think it's tequila,
right Casamigos? And that's great for him
because his customer acquisition

cost is incredibly low because
he's George freakin Clooney. And that's great. He can just like print money.

Same thing with the Kardashians. It's like they pick
a commodity thing. They go and they print
money in that commodity

on the back of their
low-customer acquisition cost. I think a lot of people
in Silicon Valley that are super talented,
have a big brand they're

doing the most
logical thing, they're starting enterprise
SaaS companies. They're like, I can do this.

It's going to be really easy. The tech barrier is really low. I have an advantage
in distribution. I'm just going to
kick everybody's butt.

I'm going to make
a ton of money. I would call that
a pretty bad quest. We need our best
people to be focused

on the most important things,
not the least important things. The challenge is that defense
tech is really, really hard.

It's not only really, really
hard from a tech perspective, it's really, really hard
for from a distribution perspective.

And it requires
a lot of capital. It requires a lot of know-how. It requires a lot
of relationships.

And so I always love
seeing young people that are super passionate about this
go out and start companies.

The challenge is you
need some more heft. You can't just go and like YOLO
a field of dreams defense tech

company. If you build it,
they will not come. That's not how it works. You need to actually
know what you're doing.

And so my hopes and
dreams for the sector, it's great to see that there's
so much more interest now

than there was in 2017. I think there's more of an
awareness in the most talented

people in the world that we have
not reached the end of history. There are still bad people
that are doing bad things,

and we have to have
some sort of control over that in the international
geopolitical scene.

I think people
are also realizing that this isn't a zero-interest
free money factory anymore.

You can't just run out and
start a blockchain company and expect that
you're going to make

a trillion dollars next week. SBF is in jail now. That didn't work. [LAUGHTER] And so I think that
people are starting

to come back to this
idea like they want to work on important things. And so that's
really good to see.

I think it's just
really important to think through
what are the things that you need to be able
to pull off in order

to build a successful company. And as a result,
I would encourage people that want to work in
this space to maybe go and spend

some time at a SpaceX, the
Palantir and Anduril, or Shield AI, something like that. Government stuff.

Government stuff. Go and get a sense for--
yeah, innovation labs. Go get a sense for like
how this stuff works

so that you're not just like-- This is not the founder vibe. Talk about that. Yeah. Stanford, you guys are way
more responsible for this

than any other college
from what I can tell. There's like a
vibes founder thing going on where it's like--

another way of putting this
is like a whiteboard founder. It's like the only
thing for sure is that you want
to be a founder,

but you don't know
